item.description:

[quote=“tigerclan, post:4, topic:539349”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=658184.msg4402484#msg4402484 date=1390970917]

[code]#include

using namespace std;
int lowest (int, int, int);

int main()
{
int num1=0;
int num2=0;
int num3=0;

cout<<"Enter any three numbers."<<endl;

cout<<endl;
cin>>num1;
cin>>num2;
cin>>num3;

lowest ( num1, num2, num3);
return 0;

}
int lowest(int num1, int num2, int num3)
{
{ // <-- hmm, this is odd…
if (num1 < num2 && num3)
{
cout<<num1 <<" is the lowest"<<endl;
}
else if (num2 < num1 && num3)
{
cout<<num2<<" is the lowest"<<endl;
}
else (num3 < num1 && num2);
{
cout<<num3<<" is the lowest"<<endl;
}
}
[/code]
I believe this is right.
Look at the differences, some parts of yours don’t make sense logically
[/quote]

Well it’s not[/quote]
My bad I didn’t correctly check for braces (I don’t have a c++ IDE, get over it)

item.title: C++ Help!
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:3, topic:539349”]You don’t seem to understand C++ syntax just yet. Keep studying. Those curly braces are to separate everything into little bits of code, so that you can use them together.[/quote]This.

The only reason I’m going to help you is because tigerclan decided it was appropriate to randomly bump dead topics and give the OP hope. I included one suggestion in the file and another one would be to make it handle erroneous input (ie not numbers), you could attempt a cast and catch an exception or run it through regex (lol).

[code=cpp]/*

  • File: main.cpp
  • Author: Pure_
  • Simple application to get the lowest of three numbers, another way would be
  • to store the numbers in an array and using a sorting algorithm, then get the
  • value of index 0 in the sorted array. A better way would be to just loop through
  • an integer array, holding onto the value of the highest number then returning it
  • at the end.
    */

#include <stdlib.h>
#include

using namespace std;

/*

  • Gets the lowest number out of the three provided.
    */
    int get_lowest(int, int, int);

/*

  • Gets the highest number out of the three provided.
    */
    int get_highest(int, int, int);

/*

  • Main method.
    /
    int main(int argc, char    * argv) {
    // Declaring our integers to hold the values we read from the user
    // You should explicitly state their starting value, in C/C++
    // their starting values can be ‘random’ - in this case it wouldn’t matter
    // though.
    int num1;
    int num2;
    int num3;

    // Reading input, a slightly user-friendly way
    cout << "Enter a number: ";
    cin >> num1;
    cout << "Enter a number: ";
    cin >> num2;
    cout << "Enter a number: ";
    cin >> num3;

    // Printing the lowest number
    cout << "The lowest number is: " << get_lowest(num1, num2, num3) << endl;

    // Printing the highest number
    cout << "The highest number is: " << get_highest(num1, num2, num3) << endl;

    return (EXIT_SUCCESS);
    }

int get_highest(int num1, int num2, int num3) {
// Checking if number 1 is higher then number 2 and number 3 (we also
// check if it’s equal or it yields unexpected results, if a couple off
// the numbers are equal in value).
if (num1 >= num2 && num1 >= num3) {
return num1;
} else if (num2 >= num1 && num2 >= num3) {
return num2;
} else {
// At this point num3 is the only remaining variable, it’s obviously
// the highest.
return num3;
}
}

int get_lowest(int num1, int num2, int num3) {
// Same logic as above, but we check for the ‘inverse’, ie if it’s smaller
// than the other two numbers.
if (num1 <= num2 && num1 <= num3) {
return num1;
} else if (num2 <= num1 && num2 <= num3) {
return num2;
} else {
// At this point num3 is the only remaining variable, it’s obviously
// the lowest.
return num3;
}
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: C++ Help!
item.dc:creator: @blood_shade blood shade
item.description:
@blood_shade wrote:

I am getting the error "undefined reference to “lowest (int, int ,int )’” in my code what is my problem?

Here is my code

[code]#include

using namespace std;

int lowest (int, int, int);

int main()
{
int num1=0;
int num2=0;
int num3=0;

cout<<"Enter any three numbers."<<endl;

cout<<endl;

int lowest(int num1, int num2, int num3);

    cin>>num1;
    cin>>num2;
    cin>>num3;
    {
    if (num1 < num2 && num3)
    {
        cout<<num1 <<" is the lowest"<<endl;
    }
    else if (num2 < num1 && num3)
    {
        cout<<num2<<" is the lowest"<<endl;
    }
    else (num3 < num1 && num2);
    {
        cout<<num3<<" is the lowest"<<endl;
    }
}

return lowest ( num1, num2, num3);

[/code]

Read full topic
